children.text: This episode centers on a conversation between Maria Martin and Luis Valdez, founder of El Teatro Campesino. It aired on March 31, 2001.

content.caption: Credit: Center for the Study of Political Graphics
El Teatro Campesino founder and member Luis Valdez performing, Berkeley, California, 1967. (Emmon Clarke courtesy CSUN University Library Digital Collections)

children.text: El Teatro Campesino was born out of the Delano Grape Strike in 1965 when Luis Valdez pitched the idea of theatre by and for farm workers to Cesar Chavez. It became the cultural arm of the United Farmworkers Movement. Humble beginnings of one act socio-political skits that dramatized the plight and cause of the immigrant farmworkers led to critical acclaim. By the 1980’s the company had toured across the United States and México, with six major tours throughout Europe.

content.caption: Luis Valdez with the cast of the 1978 production of “Zoot Suit” at the Mark Taper Forum. Credit: Jay Thompson

children.text: In 1978 Luis Valdez created Zoot Suit, according to their website it is one of the most successful plays ever to originate in Los Angeles and the first play by a Latino to be presented on Broadway. Zoot Suit also landed a motion picture deal with Universal Studios.

This opened the door for Luis Valdez to write and direct La Bamba, the story of Ritchie Valens. El Teatro Campesino and Luis Valdez’s legacy is considered a major catalyst for the explosion of Chicano arts. According to American Theatre Magazine, “The Teatro gave Chicano audiences in particular a sense of belonging in a society that had ignored and suppressed them for generations.” Themes of cultural identity, prejudice and discrimination are central to several of Luis Valdez’s works. According to El Paso Matters, La Bamba and Zoot Suit were added to the National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being “culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant.”
